required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Trial of Cranberry Capsules for Urinary Tract Infection Prevention in Nursing Home Residents
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Controlled Trial of Cranberry Capsules for UTI Prevention in Nursing Home Residents

brief_summary.textblock: Urinary tract infection (UTI) is the most common infection in nursing home residents, and bacteriuria is the greatest trigger for antimicrobial therapy in the nursing home setting. The primary aim of this study is to test the efficacy of two oral cranberry capsules per day in the reduction of bacteriuria plus pyuria in female nursing home residents. These aims will be accomplished by conducting a double blind randomized placebo controlled efficacy trial of two oral cranberry capsules daily versus placebo in a cohort of Connecticut female nursing home residents.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants were randomized to cranberry or placebo capsules.
study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Participants With Urine Cultures With Bacteriuria (>100,000 Cfu/ml or >=100,000 Cfu/ml) Plus Pyuria (Any WBC)
primary_outcome.description: Clean catch urine cultures and urinalyses will be obtained every two months for each participant for study purposes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Episodes of Symptomatic UTI
secondary_outcome.description: Suspected UTI episodes that are recorded in the medical record by the primary provider will be reviewed by chart review, symptoms will be recorded, and two adjudicators will determine if the definition of symptomatic UTI is met.
Chart review will be performed to determine the names and duration of antibiotic prescriptions prescribed by the primary provider on each participant.

All urine culture data will be reviewed to determine presence of multidrug-resistant gram-negative bacilli (resistance to ≥3 of the following antibiotics: ampicillinsulbactam,cefazolin, ceftriaxone, ceftazidime, fluoroquinolones, piperacillin-tazobactam, meropenem, imipenem, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Antibiotic Prescriptions for Suspected UTI
secondary_outcome.description: Chart review will be performed to determine the names and duration of antibiotic prescriptions prescribed by the primary provider on each participant's suspected UTI.

secondary_outcome.measure: Subjects With 1, 2, or 3 Episodes of UTIs
secondary_outcome.description: Suspected UTI episodes that are recorded in the medical record by the primary provider will be reviewed by chart review, symptoms will be recorded, and two adjudicators will determine if the definition of symptomatic UTI is met.

other_outcome.measure: Number of Adverse Events in Participants
Adherence to Capsule Intake by All Participants
other_outcome.description: measured by capsules removed from blister packs

intervention.description: Two cranberry capsules qd (each capsule containing 36mg proanthocyanidin, total 72mg PAC)
Two placebo capsules qd (each capsule containing 36mg proanthocyanidin, total 72mg PAC)

facility.name: Arden House Care and Rehabilitation Center
Wadsworth Glen Health Care and Rehabilitation Center
Water's Edge Center for Health & Rehabilitation
Advanced Nursing & Rehab Center of New Haven

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruited from nursing homes within 50 miles of New Haven.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 806 patients were eligible, 558 declined to participate. Of the 248 consented, 63 were found to be ineligible after consent, leaving 185 to randomize.

group.title: 2 Cranberry Capsules
group.description: Experimental: 2 cranberry capsules 2 cranberry capsules: Two cranberry capsules qd (each capsule containing 36mg proanthocyanidin, total 72mg PAC)

group.title: 2 Placebo Capsules
group.description: Experimental: 2 placebo capsules qd Placebo: Two placebo capsules qd (each capsule containing 36mg proanthocyanidin, total 72mg PAC)

baseline.population: Inclusion criteria were (1) female; (2) long-term care residents; (3) English speaking; and (4) 65 years or older.

group.title: 2 Cranberry Capsules
group.description: Experimental: 2 cranberry capsules 2 cranberry capsules: Two cranberry capsules qd (each capsule containing 36mg proanthocyanidin, total 72mg PAC)

group.title: 2 Placebo Capsules
group.description: Experimental: 2 placebo capsules qd Placebo: Two placebo capsules qd (each capsule containing 36mg proanthocyanidin, total 72mg PAC)

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Participants With Urine Cultures With Bacteriuria (>100,000 Cfu/ml or >=100,000 Cfu/ml) Plus Pyuria (Any WBC)
outcome.description: Clean catch urine cultures and urinalyses will be obtained every two months for each participant for study purposes.
outcome.population: 147 subjects completed 1 year, 33 died. 20 subjects, 9 in the treatment group v 11 in the control group, became incontinent prior to the first time point, thus unable to provide any urine. 45 subjects stopped taking the capsules, 24 in treatment and 21 in control; 21 refused, 19 transitioned to hospice, 4 started warfarin, and 1 refused via family.

outcome.title: Subjects With 1, 2, or 3 Episodes of UTIs
outcome.description: Suspected UTI episodes that are recorded in the medical record by the primary provider will be reviewed by chart review, symptoms will be recorded, and two adjudicators will determine if the definition of symptomatic UTI is met.
outcome.population: There were 10 symptomatic UTIs in the treatment group (8 participants with 1 episode and 1 participant with 2 episodes) and 12 symptomatic UTIs in the control group (7 participants with 1 episode, 1 participant with 2 episodes, and 1 participant with 3 episodes).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
